fields: iNOS is “inducible” in the presence of {{c1::Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNFa)}}, {{c2::gIFN}} and some microbial products such as {{c3::LPS}}

{{c1::Bacterial Endotoxins (LPS)}} 
1) are produced by {{c2::Gram neg bacteria }}
2) is composed of a {{c3::lipid core or backbone (called Lipid A)}} and {{c3::numerous carbohydrate side chains}}
3) Has great {{c4::variablility}} between strains
4) Is stable at {{c5::high temperatures }}
5) CANNOT be made into a {{c6::toxoid}}
6) Can act as an {{c7::exogenous pyrogen that in turns activate endogenous pyrogen}}

Because the composition and complexity of the carbohydrate side chains is highly variable from one Gram-negative bacterium to another, the antigenic structure of LPS is also highly variable from one Gram-negative bacterium to another. This means that it is unlikely that neutralizing antibodies resulting from one exposure to LPS will induce protective immunity against another LPS from a different Gram-negative bacterium.
LPS is an exogenous pyrogen that induces the sequential production of endogenous pyrogens: {{c1::IL-1}}, {{c2::TNF-alpha}}, and {{c3::IL-6}}
LPS has the ability to disrupt the blood brain barrier

{{c1::Peptidoglycan}} is a fabric shell of woven {{c2::N-acetyl-glucosamine (NAGs)}} and {{c2::Nacetylmuramic acid (NAMs)}} that limits {{c2::the volume of water that can move into bacterial cytoplasms}}, preventing cell lysis
{{c1::Muramic acid residues}} of seperated peptidoglycan residues are linked through the peptide stems/amino acid sidechains
This creates cross links which ultimately gives the cell wall it's strength
Most bacteria maintain a {{c1::hypertonic}} osmotic pressure with respect to their environment
This means that's osmotic gradient favors water entering the cell causing swelling, peptidoglycan prevents the cell from bursting

The following bacteria do not posses peptidoglycan:
1: {{c1::Mycoplasma}}
2: {{c2::Rickettsia}} 
3: {{c3::Chlamydia}} 
4: {{c4::Ehrlichia}} 
5: {{c5::Anaplama}}
This affects treatment; these bacteria are not affected by penicillin or cephalospin

The Gram negative cell wall is characterized by 
1) {{c1::An outer membrane composed of phospholipds and LPS }}
2) {{c2::Periplasm, which contains a small peptidoglycan layer }}
3) {{c3::A cytoplasmic lipid bilayer }}
{{c1::Periplasm}} of a Gram-negative cell, is located between the {{c2::outer}} and {{c2::inner membranes}} and serves to {{c3::provide structural rigidity to the cell }}
The peptidoglycan only about 1 layer thick, much thinner than that found in Gram-positive bacteria (why Gram-negative bacteria are less susceptible to cell-wall active agents.

Besides providing structural rigidity, other functions of the periplasm include:
1. {{c1::Nutrient uptake from OM to CM}} 
2. {{c2::Sensory (chemotaxis) mechanism}} 
3. {{c3::Degradative enzymes}}
4. {{c4::Osmoregulation}}
Only {{c1::gram-negative}} bacteria possess an outer membrane

The outermembrane of gram-neg bacteria are imperiable to {{c1::hydrophillic substances}} and therefore gram neg bacteria are resistant to:
1. {{c2::Dyes}}
2. {{c3::Detergents}} 
3. {{c4::Hydrolytic Enzymes (lysozome)}}

Functions of the outer membrane of Gram- neg bacteria include: 
i. {{c1::Contains virulence and toxicity factors.}}
ii. {{c2::Site of major antigenic components (e.g., O-antigen in Gram- negatives)}} 
iii. {{c3::Macromolecules components are receptors for antibodies, sex pilus, bacteriophages }} 
iv. {{c4::Anchors external structures of the bacteria, e.g., flagella, capsules}}.
{{c1::Porins}} are {{c2::outmembrane}} proteins that serve as {{c3::channels for specific hydrophillic substances }}
{{c1::Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)}} is composed of a {{c2::Lipid A (endotoxin)}}, a {{c2::core polysaccharide}}, and an {{c2::O-specific polysaccharide chain (O-antigen) }}
{{c1::Lipid A}} (aka {{c2::Endotoxin}}) is a polymer composed of a {{c2::disaccharide}}, {{c2::phosphate}}, and {{c2::fatty acids. }}
Lipid A is not the same in all bacteria, the fatty acid side chain length can vary and modification of glycol-phosphate backbone can also occur

{{c1::Core oligosaccharide }} of LPS  may contain {{c2::sugars}}, {{c2::amino sugars}}, {{c2::sugar acids}} or {{c2::sugar alcohols}} and often contain a uniqure sugar called {{c3::ketodeoxyoctulonate (KDO)}}
KDO is common in enteric bacteria
{{c1::Terminal polysaccharide (AKA the O-antigen) }} of LPS are terminal N repeating units of {{c2::sugars}}, {{c2::amino}} sugar, sugar {{c2::acids}}, & sugar {{c2::alcohols}}

Is highly specific, e.g., The O-antigens of Salmonella are chemically
different from those of Escherichia.

Is highly variable e.g., the genus Salmonella possesses thousands of
strains, each strain possessing a chemically distinct O-antigen.
{{c2::Lipooligiosaccharide (LOS)}} contains {{c3::Lipid A}} and the {{c3::extend core}}, it lacks {{c1::O-antigen }}
LOS is synthesized in place of LPS in {{c1::Neisseria meningitidis}}, {{c2::N. gonorrhoeae}}, {{c3::Haemophilus influenzae}} and {{c4::H. ducreyi}}
LOS tends to be similar to certain human surface molecules and therefore can avoid detection

LPS induces the release of these endogenous mediators: 
1. {{c1::TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6 = “early”}}
2. {{c2::Arachidonic acid metabolites}}
3. {{c3::Bradykinin}}
4. {{c4::Histamines}}
5. {{c5::Nitric Oxide (NO)}}
6. {{c6::Free radicals, especially superoxide anions}}
{{c1::Systemic Inflammatroy Response syndrome (SIRS) }} is a system wide activation of an immune response by {{c2::macrophages}}, {{c2::PMNs}} and {{c2::endothelial cells }}
The SIRS pathway can be activated by either {{c1::infection}} or{{c1:: Non-infectious}}

Each is responsible for about 1/2 of SIRS cases

LPS is a prominent activator of SIRS in infectious causes

Mechanism of SIRS activation by LPS/LOS
1. {{c1::Lipid A of LPS binds to LPS binding protein}}
2. {{c2::LPS-LBP complex transfers LPS to membrane bound CD14}}
3. {{c3::LPS-CD14 binds to TLR4 which then causes a signal cascade }}

LPS-LBP complex can also transfer LPS to soluable {{c1::CD14}} in the serum, which may then bind to {{c2::endothelial cells}} leading to {{c3::hypotension/vascular leak syndromes}} such as {{c4::Acute Respiratory Distress syndrome }}

Diplococcus (pairs):
1. Gram-negative genera: {{c1::Neisseria}}, {{c1::Moraxella}}, {{c1::Veillonella}}; resemble two kidney beans, side-by-side

{{c2::Diplococcus}} (pairs):
1. {{c1::Gram-negative genera:}} Neisseria, Moraxella, Veillonella resemble two kidney beans, side-by-side
2. {{c1::Gram-positive genus:}} {{c3::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} resembles two footballs, end-to-end (lancet shaped)

Bacillus:
a. Shape: bacilli/rod
i. Very short rod - {{c1::coccobacilli}} (Bordetella, Brucella, Francisella tularemia, Haemophilus spp., Yersinia spp; Gram-{{c1::negative}})
ii. Short, thin rods (Many Gram-{{c2::negative}} bacteria)
iii. Short, thin, needle-shaped rods ({{c3::fusiforms}}; Gram-{{c3::negative}} bacteria)
iv. Long, thick rods (Bacillus, Clostridium, Gram-{{c4::positive}})
v. Short, thick rods (Listeria; Gram-{{c5::positive}})
vi. Clubbed shaped rods - {{c6::diphtheroids}} (Corynebacterium spp. and Propionibacterium acnes; Gram-{{c6::positive}})
1. Thin, branching filamentous rods with clubbed endings (Actinomyces, Nocardia)

Systemic Inflammatory Syndrome is clincially defined as {{c1::2 or more::number}} of the following
1. {{c2::Temperature > 38 C (100.4 F) or < 36 C (96.8F)}}
2. {{c3::Tachycardia }}
3. {{c4::Tachypnea (RR > 20 or PaCO2 < 32 mmHg)}}
4. {{c5::Leukocytosis (WBC > 12000) or leukopenia (<4000 WBC) or >10% bands}}
A band cell (also called band neutrophil, band form or stab cell) is a cell undergoing granulopoiesis

Helicoidal:
a. Shape:
i. Curved/comma-shaped rod (Campylobacter, Helicobacter, and Vibrio - Gram-{{c1::negative}})
ii. Curved/comma-shaped rod (Mobiluncus spp. - Gram-{{c2::positive}})
iii. Spir{{c3::ochetes}} (Borrelia, Leptospira, Treponema)
iv. Spir{{c3::illum}}
Pleomorphic – can vary in {{c1::size & shape}} (Haemophilus, Gardnerella)

Sepsis/Spetic Shock has one or more of three “over-arching” pathophysiological processes:
1. {{c1::Systemic inflammation /“hyperinflammatory state”}}
2. {{c2::Activation of coagulation}}
3. {{c3::Inhibition of fibrinolysis}}

The First step in the inhibition of fibrinolysis in sepsis occurs by {{c2::activation of coagulation (fibrin deposition)}} result from LPS activating {{c1::Hageman factor (Factor XIII)}} which activates the clotting system & fibrinolysis.
The second step in the inhibition of fibrinolysis in sepsis is the {{c1::subsequent inhibition of Hageman Factor}} by {{c2::plasminogen-activator inhibitor.}}

The sudden inhibition of {{c2::Hageman Factor (Factor XIII)}} by {{c3::plasminogen acitvator inhibitor in SIRS}} can lead to the accumulation of undissolved thrombin in microcirculation leading to {{c1::Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)}}
Patients that survive the hyperinflammatory phase in sepsis enter a {{c1::protracted immunosuppression (hypoinflammatory, hypoimmune)}} state termed {{c1::“immunoparalysis”.}}

immunosuppression in sepsis is manifested by the:
a. {{c1::Loss of delayed type hypersensitivity response to positive control antigens}}
b. {{c2::Failure to clear the primary infection}}
c. {{c3::Development of new secondary infections (which may cause patient’s death)}}
d. {{c4::Reactivation of dormant viruses (herpes simplex virus [HSV-1], Epstein-Barr virus [EBV], cytomegalovirus [CMV], human herpes virus [HHV)]-7)}}
Older adults who survive an episode of severe sepsis may be left with {{c1::substantial and enduring cognitive impairment}} and {{c1::functional disability.}}

Shock is defined as {{c1::inadequate profusion of tissues}} -- there are three forms of shock:
1. {{c2::Cardiogenic}}
2. {{c3::Vascular obstructive}}
3. {{c4::Hypovolemic:}}

{{c1::Distributive Shock (DS; AKA warm shock}}) is a form of {{c2::hypovolemic shock}} characterized by {{c3::Endothelial cell dysfunction/capillary leakiness}}, {{c3::Coagulopathy/DIC}}, and {{c3::Septic Cardiomyopathy}}.

Loss of vascular resistance leads to hypotension, Is also characterized by Coagulopathy / DIC

Septic cardiomyopathy, is reversible and does not seem to involve structural damage of the heart

The clinical manifestations of Distributive Shock (hypovolemic shock):
i. {{c1::Fever or hypothermia (low body temperature)}}
ii. {{c1::Leukopenia or leukocytosis (abnormally low or high levels of peripheral WBCs}}
iii. {{c2::Tachycardia (rapid heart rate) and tachypnea (rapid breathing)}}
iv. {{c2::Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)}}
v.  {{c3::multi-organ failure (MOF) or multiple organ dysfunction (MOD)}} 
vi. {{c3::Acute kidney injury }}
Sepsis is defined as {{c1::“life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection}}

Sepsis is a syndrome without, at present, a validated criterion standard diagnostic test. There is currently no process to operationalize the definitions of sepsis and septic shock. Sepsis is a multifaceted host response to an infecting pathogen that may be significantly amplified by endogenous factors.” “For clinical operationalization, organ dysfunction can be represented by an increase in the Sequential [Sepsis-related] Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA)”

The quickSOFA (suick sepsis related organ failure assessment) uses three symptoms to asses patients for possible sepsis ({{c4::2 of 3}} required):
1. {{c1::Hypotension of 100mmHg or below}}
2. {{c2::Tachypnea of at least 22 breaths per min}}
3. {{c3::Altered mental status }}
Score out of 3, one point for each

{{c1::Septic shock}} is a subset of sepsis in which circulatory, cellular, & metabolic abnormalities are associated with a {{c2::greater risk of mortality than sepsis alone}} and is characterized by:
1.{{c3:: Needing to use vasopressors or vasoactive medication to maintain mean arterial blood pressure of 65mm Hg or higher after adequate fluid resuscitation is not effective }}
2. {{c4::The presence of a high lactate (more than 2 mmol/L) after fluid recuscitation }}

An increase in the serum lactate level is positioned as a proxy for a cellular metabolic abnormality, and as a variable independently associated with acute mortality (predictive validity). It is not specific for cellular dysfunction in sepsis but has face validity given the lack of a superior yet readily available alternative

c. Medically important Gram-positive cocci
S{{c1::treptococcus}}
S{{c1::taphylococcus}}
E{{c1::nterococcus}}

d. Medically important "lancet-shaped" diplococci
Streptococcus {{c2::pneumoniae}}

e. Genera of bacterial endospore-formers
C{{c3::lostridium}}
B{{c3::acillus}}

f. Genera of medically important Gram-(-) "{{c5::kidney-bean}}" shaped diplococci
N{{c5::eisseria}}
V{{c5::eillonella}}
M{{c5::oraxella}}

g. Genera of Gram negative comma ({{c6::vibrio}}) shaped bacteria
V{{c6::ibrio}}
H{{c6::elicobacter}}
C{{c6::ampylobacter}}

Significance: Bacteria cannot be identified based on size, shape, cell arrangement, or Gram-stain reaction alone. However, the results of a Gram-stained clinical specimen:
a. Often {{c1::determines/influences}} initial antimicrobial therapy
b. Aids in {{c1::identification}} of the etiologic agent

Cell surface structures:

A. All lie on top of/on the surface of the cell wall and extend out from cell surface into environment.
B. Can be present in both {{c1::Gram-positive}} and {{c1::Gram-negative}} bacteria.

C. A particular bacterial species can have any combination of these, that is they may possess NONE, one, two or all three of these structures. Bacteria can be human pathogens and lack flagella, pili, or capsules, but these 3 structures are often present on human pathogenic bacteria.
D. These structures are all constructed from a monomeric unit, repeated N number of times. As such they are {{c2::Type II-}}T-independent antigens. Highly variable antigenic epitopes means {{c3::little}} cross-reactivity between serotypes, which means they are often {{c3::not good}} candidates for vaccines.

Flagella (AKA {{c1::H}}-antigen) – are composed of protein:

2. Protein composition:
a. {{c2::Repeating poly}}peptide units
b. {{c2::Different}} primary amino acid sequence than pili polypeptide units

3. Types/structure:
a. {{c3::Plain}} (extend out from cell surface into environment)
b. {{c3::Endoflagella}} of spirochetes (internal structure)

4. Function:
a. Provide {{c4::motility}}:
i. Primarily in liquid
ii. Some surface translocation

b. Flagella are controlled by a sensory system to {{c5::move}} cell toward or away from substances ({{c5::chemotaxis}}).

5. Clinical significance:
a. Flagella/H-antigen - aids in {{c6::identification}} of bacteria.
b. Are a {{c6::virulence}} factor: motility with chemotaxis in response to sensing their environment.

Pili (Fimbriae; Latin for 'thread' or 'fiber) – are composed of protein:

2. Protein composition:
a. {{c1::Repeating poly}}peptide units
b. {{c1::Different}} primary amino acid sequence than flagella polypeptide units.

3. Types/structure:
.
i. There are 4 types of pili (types I to IV)

4. Function/Clinical significance of:
a. Normal pili:
i. {{c2::Aid in adherence}} to host cells – are a {{c2::virulence}} factor
  2 component adherence system: bacteria produces a protein that binds to a human surface component and then the pili adhesion binds to the bacterial protein, e.g., Enterotoxigenic E. coli

ii. Are {{c3::anti}}phagocytic – are a {{c3::virulence}} factor

iii. Motility Certain normal (type {{c4::IV}}) pili are specifically involved in a form of motility, called {{c4::surface translocation/twitching}} motility which is a virulence factor for many human pathogens

v. {{c6::auto-aggregation}} of cells as micro-colonies on epithelial cells
vi. i{{c6::ntra}}cellular signaling 
vii. {{c6::horizontal}} gene transfer - competency 

b. {{c7::Sex}} pilus plays a role in conjugation, an important process in spread of antibiotic resistance determinants among bacteria.

Capsules (AKA {{c1::glycocalyx}}, {{c1::exopolysaccharides}} [EPS]):

2. Structure: {{c2::mucoid}}-like (mucous) coat around the cell which are:
a. {{c2::Cell}}–surface associated
b. {{c2::Slime}} layer (cell-free/soluble in water, not cell associated)
c. Both {{c2::cell}}–surface associated and a {{c2::slime}} layer
3. Composition: usually {{c3::poly}}saccharide polymers may consist of either a, b, c, or d:
a. Repeating units of a {{c4::single sugar}} molecule e.g., dextran or levan.
b. Repeating units of {{c4::complex}} polysaccharides - sugars, sugar alcohols, amino sugars, sugar acids, etc., creates many antigenically distinct capsules.
c. Repeating units of {{c4::D-glutamic}} acid (form a polypeptide; Bacillus anthracis).
Note a., b., and c., are {{c5::K}} antigens, d. is not.
* Are hydrophilic in nature; hence antiphagocytic.
d. In some Gram-negative bacteria, the {{c6::O}}-antigen of LPS is the capsule and then no {{c6::K}} antigen is expressed.

Biofilms:

a. “Biofilms, communities of bacteria that live together for the benefit of the group, are characterized by:
i. {{c1::Water}} channels
ii. {{c1::Complex three-dimensional}} structures
iii. An i{{c1::ncreased}} resistance to environmental stresses.”
b. Biofilm formation is a multi-step developmental process that includes at least five distinguishable steps:
i. {{c2::Reversible}} attachment
ii. {{c2::Irreversible}} attachment and production of adhesive molecules such as {{c2::exopoly}}saccharides
iii. Biofilm development characterized by a distinct {{c3::mushroom}} shape
iv. Biofilm {{c3::maturation}}
v. Biofilm {{c3::dispersal}}

Biofilms:

A protected, complex, 3-dimensional structure - A community of {{c1::bacterial}} or {{c1::yeast}} cells, in which microcolonies enmeshed in a {{c1::mucoid}} (hydrated) exopolysaccharide film (produced by the cells in the microcolonies) adhere to wet surfaces (inert or living):
In some biofilms proteins (amyloid fibers AKA Curli; Curli fibers) are also a constituent.

Biofilms:

Bacteria in biofilms undergo {{c1::phe}}notypic (not {{c1::genotypic}}) changes:

i. {{c2::Quorum}} sensing is involved in the activation of biofilm formation.
ii. Motile bacteria become {{c2::sessile}} (non-motile) while in the biofilm.

Bacteria in biofilms undergo phenotypic (not genotypic) changes:
i. Quorum sensing is involved in the activation of biofilm formation.

ii. Motile bacteria become sessile (non-motile) while in the biofilm.

iii. Bacteria in the biofilm persist even in the presence of {{c1::antimicrobial}} agents to which they are {{c1::normally}} susceptible to in the planktonic state. They are {{c1::multidrug resistant (MDR)}}, often to extraordinarily high concentrations of antibiotics.

iv. Some cells in the biofilm {{c2::revert}} to the “normal”/planktonic form” and are {{c2::released back}} into the environment. Clinically, this may explain some therapy failures. After antimicrobial therapy has cleared non-biofilm bacteria from the body, newly-released revertants re-seed the human body causing {{c2::recurrent}} infection.

v. Bacterial cells deep in biofilm communicate with cells in the periphery using {{c3::chemical}} gradients & {{c3::ion}} channels and control peripheral {{c3::cell metabolism}} (keep them from consuming all the food)

vi. Cells or microcolonies in a biofilm are joined by {{c4::amyloid}} proteins. The disruption of the {{c4::amyloid}} protein connections can cause the biofilm to break down. The release of nanogram amounts of certain D-A.A. can produce this disruption and are produced by the bacteria in the biofilm when the “situation” dictates that the bacteria need to be released.

Clinical significance of EPS/biofilms:
i. Avid {{c1::adherence}} to host tissues and surfaces (AKA surface colonization; such as catheters). Biofilms enable bacteria to grow/thrive in a {{c1::moving}} solution.
ii. Protection against {{c2::phagocytosis/WBC}}, {{c2::serum}} factors, {{c2::antibodies}}, (i.e., the infection is not susceptible to the host immune response).
iii. Protection against {{c3::antibiotics}}
iv. Protection against {{c3::desiccation}}
v. {{c4::Antigen}} used to identify some human pathogens, e.g., the pneumococcus. Capsules are the K antigen of bacteria.
vi. The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) estimates > ½ of all human bacterial infections (especially chronic) involve biofilms.

Note: by convention:

A. the “{{c1::H}}” antigen is a flagella antigen.
B. the “{{c1::K}}” antigen is the capsular antigen.
C. the “{{c1::O}}” antigen is the O-antigen of LPS.

S-layers (AKA {{c1::A}}- or {{c1::T}}-layers) are composed of {{c1::protein}}(s):

1. Occurrence:
a. {{c2::A single}} layer is significant percentage of cellular protein or mass (10 to 20%).
b. Present on Gram-{{c3::positive}}, Gram -{{c3::negative}} genera found in animal, environmental, human isolates, i.e., are present on some {{c3::human normal}} flora & pathogens.

2. Are not flagella, pili, capsules (EPS), LPS, biofilms, curli, or extracellular matrix.

3. Location: External layer(s) that cover the {{c4::entire cell}} surface, lies {{c4::directly}} on cell wall.
4. Structure: a {{c5::rigid}} layer with pores of {{c5::fixed}} diameter.
5. Composition: Either {{c6::protein}} or {{c6::glycoprotein}} (Often, the only glycoprotein in bacteria)
6. Functions as a {{c7::virulence}} factor:
a. Confers {{c7::resistance}} to complement mediated killing (C3b binding)
b. Prevents {{c7::phagocytosis}} by PMNs

Curli are composed of {{c1::protein}}(s):

1. Occurrence: Curli are the major {{c2::proteinaceous extracellular}} fibers and a component of a complex {{c3::extra-cellular}} matrix produced by many Enterobacteriaceae

3. Location: External layer(s) that cover the {{c4::entire cell}} surface, lies {{c4::directly}} on cell wall also important in formation of the extracellular matrix

4. Composition: {{c5::amyloid}} proteins (prions)
5. Functions as a {{c6::virulence}} factor primarily by mediating {{c6::surface}} and {{c6::cell-cell}} contacts that promote community behavior and host colonization:
a. {{c7::Adhesion}} to surfaces
b. Cell {{c7::aggregation}}
c. Biofilm f{{c7::ormation}}
d. Mediating host cell {{c7::adhesion}} and {{c7::invasion}}

Cell Movement:
A. {{c1::Translocation}}: Passage through human cells to access new sites. e.g., Haemophilus influenzae, type b., S. pyogenes, M. tuberculosis.
B. {{c2::Paracellular translocation}}: Passage between cells to enter tissues.
C. {{c3::Sliding motility on solid surfaces}} is associated with biofilm formation at least with Mycobacterium smegmatis.
Internal genotypic variation occurs due to what?
Alteration in pre-existing genetic material by mutation
The frequency of such mutations is {{c1::rare}} but the number of bacteria is {{c1::large}}, so many occur
Bacteria bearing beneficial mutations become {{c1::dominate}}/are {{c1::selected for by natural selection}}.
One cell in a population acquires a mutation which enables it to grow faster, produce more progeny than cells lacking mutation. Eventually, {{c1::daughter cells (progeny)}} dominate the population.

What are some examples of clinically significant mutations?

1)Some bacterial species have developed mutations in the {{c1::transpeptidase genes}} - which resulted in {{c1::resistance to penicillin}}.

2) Recent mutations in the {{c2::β-lactamase (penicillin resistance) gene of the enterococci}} resulted in expanded resistance to {{c2::synthetic penicillins and the βlactamase inhibitors.}}
Are mutations a mechanism to transfer new genes to other bacteria?

NO, 

Mutations create new genes with new functions but it is not a mechanism to transfer these new genes to other bacteria
Horizontal Gene Transfer cannot {{c1::create new genes}}  but it can {{c1::spread existing genes to many bacteria.}}

Transfer of genetic information (DNA) from one bacterial cell to another mediated by either:

– Transformation 
– Conjugation 
– Transduction

The external genetic information exchanged is: 

– Carried on/contained in: 
{{c1::»Plasmid }}
{{c2::»Virus/Bacteriophage-generalized transduction}} 
{{c3::»Virus/Bacteriophage-lysogenic transduction}}

– Naked DNA in solution - {{c4::segment of a bacterial genome or a plasmid}}.

The exchange of external genetic information occurs when: 
{{c1::– Recombination takes place }}
{{c2::– A new plasmid is acquired }}
{{c3::– Generalized Transduction or Lysogeny takes place}}

External genetic information is exchanged when:

{{c1::
Highly homologous genes (chromosomal or plasmid genes encoding altered function) from the donor replace, via recombination, the corresponding chromosomal or plasmid genes in the recipient cell
}}

{{c2::A plasmid (bearing new or altered genes) from a donor cells is acquired by the recipient and establishes residency in the recipient cell -- a new plasmid is acquired}}

{{c3::A latent bacteriophage/prophage (carrying new or altered genes) establishes residency in the recipient cell}} by either: 
{{c4::» Integrating into the recipient cell's chromosome }}
{{c5::»Functioning as a plasmid in the recipient’s cytoplasm}}
{{c1::Horizontal gene transfer}} has resulted in the transfer of antibiotic resistance between/among bacteria.
{{c1::Acinetobacter baumannii}}, a major cause of hospital-acquired infections worldwide.
Researchers have discovered a cluster of 45 genes coding for antibacterial drug resistance on a {{c1::resistance island.}}

What are the commonalities between the 3 different methods of horizontal gene transfer?

{{c1::Gene transfer always involves a donor cell and a recipient cell. }}

{{c2::The donor cell may be alive as in conjugation or lysed as in transformation and generalized transduction}}.

{{c3::The recipient cell is always alive.}}

Transformation is the horizontal transfer of genetic information which occurs via the uptake of {{c1::“naked”- extracellular plasmid, viral, or chromosomal DNA}} by a {{c1::bacterial cell}} (the recipient).
DNA uptake is by a mechanism encoded by the {{c1::recipient cell’s chromosome.}}
Mechanism: Only {{c1::competent cells}} are capable of accumulating “naked” DNA into the recipient cell’s cytoplasm.

Two forms of competent cells exist: 

– {{c1::Naturally competent genes for competency are activated by environmental-cell cycle factors}}. 

– {{c2::“Forced” competency is where physical or chemical treatments induce competency.}}

Actual process of transformation: 
1) {{c1::The donor cell dies and lyses }}
2) {{c2::Releasing “naked” DNA into the environment }}
3) “Naked” – extracellular DNA consists of: 
    {{c3:: » Its fragmented DNA genome into environment}} 
     {{c4::» Plasmid and/or viral DNA, if present}} 
4) {{c5::The recipient cell accumulates (takes up) any extracellular DNA. }}
Accumulation occurs by a complex mechanism encoded on the recipient cell’s chromosome.

If homologous sequences are involved, integration of donor DNA requires {{c1::RecA}} and the presence of {{c1::homologous sequences}} on both segments of donor and recipient DNA (host genome or plasmid).
For transformation, If a plasmid is transferred that can replicate in the recipient cell, no {{c1::RecA}} is required.
For transformation, DNA not integrated into host chromosome or plasmid is {{c1::degraded.}}

Important organisms which can be transformed:

{{c1::»Haemophilus}} 
{{c2::»Neisseria – type 4 pili are involved}} 
{{c3::»Staphylococcus }}
{{c4::»Streptococcus}}

What are limitations of transformation?
– {{c1::Not all bacteria are naturally competent. }}
– {{c2::Unless significant homology exists between donor & recipient DNA , the accumulated Donor DNA will be degraded by recipient cell enzymes.}}

Clinical significance of transformation?

Has resulted in the spread of {{c1::antibiotic resistance and virulence factors among bacteria}}.

What are some characteristics of conjugation?

 The horizontal transfer of genetic information - DNA (a copy of the plasmid or conjugative transposon) [an ECE] from the donor to the recipient cell. 
 The mechanism encoded by the plasmid or conjugative transposon present in the {{c1::donor cell}}. 
 {{c2::Donor cell}} must be alive.
 Any incidental transfer of Donor cell chromosomal DNA is {{c3::very rare and may not even be possible with certain plasmids or conjugative transposons.}}
What are the {{c1::3}} distinct mechanisms of conjugation
The most common mechanism of conjugation is?
Conjugative mechanisms present on plasmids which replicate in Gram-negative bacteria.
What is an example of the conjugative mechanism on plasmids which replicate in gram-negative bacteria?
Example is Drug resistance mediated by resistance factors (R-factors) from Gram-negative bacteria
Plasmids encoding for antibiotic resistance are called {{c1::Resistance Factors (R-factors)}}
Conjugative plasmids that replicate in {{c1::Gram negative bacteria}} often carry R-factors.
Conjugation by R-plasmids is called {{c1::Infectious drug resistance}} (conjugative transfer of antibiotic resistance) because it is mediated by plasmids that are R-factors.

In conjugation, mating occurs. What is mating?

- {{c1::cell to cell contact between donor and recipient}}
Mating is essential and as used here does not mean sexual reproduction
In mating, Sex pili functions to make initial contact between cells under {{c1::some, not all conditions.}}
In mating, A ssDNA copy of {{c1::R-factor (plasmid)}} is transferred from the donor to the recipient cell via a {{c1::pore in the fused cell membranes}} of the donor and recipient.
n conjugation, {{c1::DNA replication in the donor cell}} drives transfer of a ssDNA copy of the R-factor.
DNA replication in the donor cell is Rolling circle replication of the plasmid DNA
In conjugation, The single-stranded copy (ssDNA copy) in recipient cell is made double stranded copy (dsDNA copy) by host cell {{c1::DNA Polymerase}}.
No RecA or site specific recombination is involved.
Conjugative plasmids have a host range/limits to which bacteria they can transfer to.
What is the clinical significance of conjugation?
Important mode of gene transmission in enteric bacteria
Transduction is the horizontal transfer of genetic information from a donor to a recipient cell mediated by a {{c1::bacteriophage.}}

In transduction, genetic information includes: 

– {{c1::chromosomal or plasmid DNA.}} 

– {{c2::acquisition of a latent bacteriophage bearing gene(s)}}
To understand the process of transduction, we first must study how {{c1::viruses infect bacteria}}.

There are two forms of viruses (bacteriophages) which can infect bacteria:
{{c1::– lytic bacteriophage.}}
{{c2::– temperate bacteriophages.}}

What is the life cycle of a lytic bacteriphage?

1) {{c1::The bacteriophage binds to specific surface component on the recipient cell’s surface. }}
2) {{c2::Viral nucleic acid (genome) enters the cytoplasm of the recipient cell. }}
3) {{c3::Viral genome is replicated - many copies are made.}} 
4) {{c4::Later, viral genome is transcribed and translated -viral core and coat proteins are made.}} 
5) {{c5::Viral genome and core and coat proteins self-assemble into infectious particles. }}
6) {{c6::Host cell releases new infectious particles via lyses or slow release.}}
A virus can either choose lytic or latency. A temparate bacteriophage chooses {{c1::latency.}}

How does latency of the temperate phage occur?

1) {{c1::Phage represses phage genes which encodes for productive cycle of phage replication.}}
2) {{c2::The latent virus (prophage) will exists as DNA in the bacterial cell (a prophage)}} *
3) {{c3::The prophage replicates in synchrony with host DNA and is passed to all daughter cells.}}

The latent virus (prophage) will exists as DNA in the bacterial cell (a prophage) as either: 
» a functional plasmid in host cytoplasm. 
» integrates into the host chromosome.
How does the latency period end with temperate phage?
Ends when phage genes which encode for productive/lytic cycle of phage replication are derepressed & the lytic cycle ensues.

The lytic cycle will result in a {{c1::productive viral infection with lysis of the host cell.}}

The temperate cycle will result in {{c2::partitioning of the prophage genome to each daughter cell.}}

There are two forms of horizontal gene transfer involving bacteriophages:

-{{c1::Generalized Transduction. }}
-{{c2::Lysogenic conversion}}
Generalized (abortive) transduction occurs with {{c1::defective phage particles}}.
Generalized (abortive) transduction process can occur in {{c1::lytic or temperate phages}}
Generalized (abortive) transduction may require {{c1::RecA}}, depending upon the nature of transduced genetic material

Process of abortive transduction:
1) {{c1::Plasmid or a segment of chromosomal DNA is sheared during viral replication in donor cell. }}
2) {{c2::A sheared fragment can randomly replace viral DNA. }}
3) {{c3::The fragment is “packaged” /self-assembled into viral-like particles called pseudovirus/abortive phage}}.

The pseudovirion/abortive phage function as normal infectious virion in that: 
» {{c1::they attach to the appropriate receptor on an uninfected recipient cell.}} 
» {{c2::the packaged DNA is introduced into the recipient cell cytoplasm.}}

In transduction, Unlike a normal virus, the packaged DNA is:
1) {{c1::a plasmid that can replicate in recipient cell. }}
2) {{c2::a chromosomal fragment that shares homology with a portion of the recipient chromosome and is integrated into that chromosome via RecA. }}
3) {{c3::a fragment of a plasmid that shares homology with a portion of a plasmid in the recipient and is integrated into that plasmid via RecA.}}

DNA not integrated into host chromosome is degraded

With no viral genome present, no viral reproduction can occur
What are limitations of HGT via bacteriophages?
Have host ranges - some are limited to only some strains of a particular bacterial species.
What is the clinical significance of transduction?

– Antibiotic resistance is passed between bacteria.

 – Bacterial genera include: 
» Enterococcus, 
» Streptococcus, 
» Staphylococcus.
Lysogenic conversion - when a the recipient bacterial cell acquires a new phenotype due to {{c1::acquisition of/infection by a prophage}}
InLysogenic conversion, The prophage contains/carries the genetic information which changes the phenotype of the {{c1::infected recipient bacteria cell.}}
The new phenotype can be expressed without activation of the temperate virus’ s genome.
Lysogenic conversion can occur only with {{c1::temperate phages}}

What is the mechanism of lysogenic conversion?

1) The temperate phage encodes for {{c1::an auxiliary gene not required for viral replication or any part of the viral infectious cycle. }}
2) The auxiliary encoded gene is an {{c2::exotoxin. }}
3) The exotoxin gene is regulated {{c3::separately and independently of the viral genes.}}
4) The exotoxin can be expressed {{c4::without altering repression of the phage genes which code for the lytic cycle; The exotoxin gene expression does not effect viral latency.}} 
5) The exotoxin gene {{c5::changes the phenotype of the cell carrying the gene from an exotoxin-negative to an exotoxin positive producing strain.}}
Bacterial cells bearing prophage DNA are lysogenized.
What are limiations of lysogenic conversion?
bacteriophages have host ranges - some are limited to only some strains of a particular bacterial species
What is the clinical significance of lysogenic conversion?

– Prophages can carry genes for toxin production: 
» Diphtheria toxin - Corynebacterium diphtheriae 
» Erythrogenic toxin - Streptococcus pyogenes 
» Botulism toxin - Clostridium Botulinum 
» TSST-1 toxin - Staphylococcus aureus

Example of lysogenic conversion clinically: There are 2 distinct phenotypic strains of diptheria - 

1) {{c1::non-toxigenic strains do not produce the diphtheria toxin and cannot cause disease in humans. }}
2) {{c2::toxigenic strains do produce the diphtheria toxin and cause disease in humans:}}
The toxin is encoded by a bacteriophage so only lysogenically converted cells express the toxin and cause disease in humans
The classification of strains of a bacterial species based on the pattern of phages capable of infecting the strain.

What is the process of phage typing?

Phage typing is accomplished by exposing {{c1::separate samples of the same strain of bacteria}} to {{c2::different bacteriophages}} and determining which phages were able to infect and which did not.

Multiple (separate, distinct) phages can infect the same species of bacteria.

Generally, each phage can only infect certain strains of that species.
What is the clinical significance of bacteriophages?
Phage therapy to treat human infections

What is the carry back mechanism?

{{c1::Mechanisms that allows for horizontal gene transfer occur between a GPR & a GNR}}

How? 2 possibilities

1){{c2:: A very, very rare occurrence, a conjugative plasmid in a GNR conjugates with an actinomyces cell; Recombination occurs between the GNR plasmid & a plasmid or the genome in the actinomyces}}

2) {{c3::The actinomyces cell lyses, releasing its genome; natural transformation followed by recombination or IS elements allows a GNR to take up the released DNA plasmid and acquire the new resistance mechanism}}
After transfer, how does antibiotic resistance determinants provide resistance in the presence of an antibiotic that inhibits translation?
A bacterial multidrug efflux pump composed of the three proteins acridine resistance protein A (AcrA), AcrB, and tolerance to colicin (TolC)

This AcrAB-TolC efflux pump confers natural resistance to {{c1::bile salts in Escherichia coli}} and {{c2::provides resistance to a wide range of chemical compounds present in sub-inhibitory concentrations}}

The active efflux of antibiotics through the AcrAB-TolC multidrug efflux pump also allows {{c1::acquisition of resistance}} in the presence of other antibiotics that block gene expression, such as {{c2::chloramphenicol, erythromycin, and rifampicin}}
AcrAB-TolC multidrug efflux pump is now a target for drug therapy.
What does the bacterial genome consist of?

The majority of these genes encode proteins that play roles in basic cellular functions/ housekeeping genes (e.g. translation, metabolism, architecture) and exhibit rather homogeneous G+C contents and codon usage.

What are characteristics of a flexible gene pool?

– {{c1::vary in size depending upon the bacteria. }}
– {{c2::encode for additional functions that are not essential for bacterial growth but provide advantages under particular conditions. }}
– {{c3::can be transferred laterally by HGT.}} 
– Consist of: 
{{c4::
» Genomic islands (GEIs/GIs; (>10 kb). 
» Genomic islets (<10 kb). 
» Prophages. 
» Plasmids
}}

What is in a genomic island?

» {{c1::presence of residual material from mobile genetic elements (e.g., integrases & IS elements), }}
» {{c2::presence of flanking direct repeats, }}
» {{c3::carry fragments (transfer genes) of other mobile elements, e.g., phages and plasmids, }}
Genomic islands are inserted in the vicinity of tRNA sequences, or other small RNA genes, making them unstable, i.e., can be excised.

How can genomic islands be differentiated from the native genome?

- {{c1::Atypical sequence properties}}
- {{c2::their large size(>10 Kb up to 100Kb). }}
- {{c3::presence of genes that aid in an organism's adaptation-documented virulence functions.}}

Atypical sequences: 
 abnormal %GC index, 
 codon usage bias 
 dinucleotide frequency difference
In many genomes these {{c1::Genomic islands}} are known to be associated with the survival of the organism under adverse conditions:

What are the subclasses of the genomic islands?

{{c1::GI associated with pathogenesis is often called a pathogenicity island (PAIs).}}

{{c2::GIs that contain many antibiotic resistant genes are referred to as antibiotic resistance islands (ARIs).}}
An endonuclease system (an “adaptive” endonulcease defense systems directed against phages & plasmids) found in many Eubacteria and nearly all Archaeabacteria.
What are the two components of CRISPR-Cas system?

– A locus for memory storage (the CRISPR array) 

– Cas genes that encode the machinery driving immunity including:
»modifying the memory storage. 
» destroying the invading phage or conjugative plasmid
All CRISPR-Cas immune systems are reliant on the formation of CRISPR memories, known as {{c1::spacers}}, to {{c2::facilitate future defense}}.
To form these memories, {{c1::small fragments of invader nucleic acids}} are added as spacers to the CRISPR memory banks in a process termed CRISPR adaptation

Clinical impact of CRISPR-Cas

– {{c1::Modified versions are being used to alter human genetic code to correct genetic lesions in living humans & embryos}} (still stage 1 clinical trials). 

– {{c2::A modified phage carrying a modified CRISPERCas system designed to kill a specific bacterial pathogen by cutting the pathogens genome has been used successfully treat an infected patient}}.
FtsZ molecules get anchored to the cell membrane via

FtsA and ZipA 
then other septasomal proteins get added to the complex
How do chromosomes in bacteria get separated into daughter cells prior to binary fission
ParM (tubulin/actin like molecule) pushes two progeny plasmids, moving them from midcell to two poles

key players: 

ParM-ADP- ParM-ATP gets hydrolyzed into ParM-ADP upon insertion

ParM-ATP- inserts at the interface between end of ParM filament and ParR/parC complex to allow for growth of the filament

parC- centromeric region of the plasmid onto which ParR binds 

ParR - protien found at the end of the polymeric filament, binds to parC section of the plasmid
{{c1::Horizontal gene transfer}} is the primary mechanism for the spread of antibiotic resistance in bacteria
Bacterial {{c1::microcompartments}} are large, {{c2::proteinaceous shells}} encapsulating {{c3::enzymes e.g., catabolic microcompartments found in many pathogenic microbes.}}
What is the 'S' stand for in 70S or 80S ribosome size

S= Svedberg unit (non-metric unit) the sedimentation rate at which a molecule travels to the bottom of a test tube when centrifuged. 

value depends on the mass, density and molecular shape
Nearly all rod shaped bacteria cells posses {{c1::MreB }}but cocci do not.

MreB = actin like protein forming cytoskeleton in bacterial cell 

Some plasmids code for parM a similar protien required for plasmid segregation.
Which macromolecules are part of the cytoplasmic structure and organization of procaryotes and eukaryotes?
{{c2::Primary cillia}} lack the {{c1::+2 core}}, they are still motile, but are not maximally efficient in their motility.
General size range of most bacteria?

approximately between 0.2 and 6 microns or 0.1-10 um

other things to note from this slide: limit of human vision is about 40 microns
general size of microscopic protozoa and fungi; size of viruses?

microscopic protozoa and fungi: 4-40um
viruses: 0.03-0.3 um
At what size can you see a cell with the unaided human eye?
{{c1::Bright field}} microscopy - transmitted light illuminates cells due to contract differences between {{c2::the bacteria and the medium.}}
{{c1::Dark}} field microscopy- Light scattered/ reflected by {{c2::bacteria}} is used to visualize cells to thin for bright field.
{{c1::Positive}} stains are a simple stained where the cell itself is stained.
{{c2::negative}} stains- medium is stained not cells. example would be {{c1::india ink stain}} to visualize capsules.
Gram {{c4::positive}} bacteria have {{c2::extensive peptidoglycan}} layers which retain {{c3::crystal violet-iodine complex}} after exposure to {{c1::alcohol}}.
Gram {{c1::negative}} bacteria have {{c2::thin peptidoglycan layers}} which do not retain crystal violet-iodine complex after exposure to {{c3::alcohol}}.
Which cell type (gram neg or gram pos) has an outer membrane?
Hans Christian Joachim Gram wanted to distinguish {{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} from {{c2::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}. So he discovered the gram stain. {{c3::Weigert}} added safranine 2-3 y later.
What is the first step of the gram stain? what type of cell ( gram + or -) does it stain?

Crystal violet - a primary, positive stain
Both gram pos and gram negative
What is the second step of the gram staining process and what is it's function

iodine
mordant/fixer

binds to the crystal violet in both gram pos and gram neg cells and forms crystals (that's why it's called crystal violet)
What is the third step in gram stain process-
Alcohol- decolorizer/destain - is able to clear the gram negative cell of crystal violet but not clear the gram positive cell
What is the final step in gram staining process

safranin- counter stain 
will stain the gram neg cells but not the gram pos cells
What happens if you forget to add primary stain?
all the cells will appear pink from the safranin (assuming you prformed the rest of the steps)
What happens if you forget to add the mordant?

Mordant = iodine 

you can't crystallize the violet


both gram positive and gram negative cells would decolorize  and both would appear pink
What happens if you add too much or too little alcohol?
both gram pos and gram neg would appear purple - you wouldn't have decolorized them
What happens if you forget the counter stain

the gram pos would be purple
the gram neg would be clear
All species of a genera, and all strains of that species, possess the {{c1::same}} cell wall structure and therefore the {{c2::same}} gram stain reaction.
consistency lf rxn to gram stain procedure
Gram stain reaction can vary with some cells but not because the cell wall has changed but rather because t{{c1::here is some structural damage to the cell}}
